6.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

LTC is committed to ongoing safety improvement.  A system to conduct Process Hazard Assessments is in place.  The system assures Process Hazard Assessments are conducted for each of the appropriate processes at LTC.  Recommendations from the Process Hazard Assessments are implemented to reduce risk from each of the processes.  It is the practice of LTC to reduce its hazards through the pursuit of inherently safer process design as appropriate.  Further efforts to effectively manage and reduce risk will continue to be considered as appropriate.

The mechanical systems are routinely tested to insure proper operation and performance.  Any problems found are corrected and opportunities for improvements are noted and evaluated.

Practice tabletops, functional drills and field exercises are also conducted to practice and improve the procedures for responding to emergencies.

Eli Lilly and Company (Lilly) is a leading, innovation-driven corporation committed to developing a growing portfolio of best-in-class and first-in-class pharmaceutical products that help people live longer, healthier and more active lives.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Lilly has designed and implemented, including:

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
2.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
3.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
4.  Five-Year Accident History
5.  Emergency Response Program
6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Lilly Technology Center (LTC) is committed to operating and maintaining all processes in a safe and responsible manner.  This is especially important for those processes using hazardous substances.  LTC has numerous systems in place to manage these chemicals.  Lilly uses a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to ensure the safety of employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  Lillys accidental release prevention programs and contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that are posed to employees, the public, and the environment by the use of these chemicals.

The LTC has an Integrated Contingency Plan that contains procedures on how to handle emergencies that occur.  This plan includes procedures for notification of local authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.  Additionally, individual business areas at the LTC site maintain local emergency response procedures which focus on the actions of local personnel in the event of an emergency.

The LTC plays an active role in its Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  A primary goal of the LEPC is to protect local citizens by developing a

nd maintaining a coordinated emergency response plan and working with industry to minimize the impacts of chemical hazards.  Through the LEPC, citizens can obtain information about hazardous substances handled at local facilities and about emergency planning efforts designed to successfully cope with accidents if they occur.  The LEPC maintains a coordinated emergency response plan for the community detailing operational procedures to be followed in the event of an accident involving hazardous materials.  The plan is available for public inspection.

The LTC actively supports community outreach efforts through Community Advisory Panels and neighbor groups.  These panels provide useful feedback from the community and advise Lilly on community issues.  Lilly also hosts plant tours and informative sessions for nearby neighbors.

2.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Eli Lilly produces a variety of pharmaceutical products using a variety of chemicals and processing operations.  The LTC is bounded by Raymond Street on the South, Harding Street on the West, and Morris Street on the North (plus one property to the north of Morris Street which totals 9 acres); the LTC Site is comprised of 267 total acres.  LTC North was originally opened in 1946 and LTC South in 1968.  The following regulated substances are handled at LTC in quantities above the threshold quantities established under the RMP regulations:

Toxics:  Ethylenediamine, Ammonia (conc 20% or greater), Hydrochloric acid (conc 37% or greater)

Flammables:  None

3.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The LTC is subject to OSHAs Process Safety Management requirements, as well as other OSHA requirements.  The facility is also subject to regulations by other agencies, including the Indiana Department of Environmental Management and the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

Specific prevention programs include conducting pre-startup and design ha

zard assessments, proactive maintenance programs, routine vessel inspections, emergency response training, safe-to-work programs, employee and contractor safety programs, and accident investigation programs.

Lilly is part of OSHAs Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).  OSHA has designated the LTC site as a Star site.  A Star designation is a recognition for employers who demonstrate exemplary achievement in the prevention and control of occupational safety and health hazards, the development, implementation and continuous improvement of their safety and health management system.  The LTC site was evaluated through a 3-week inspection in April and May 2023 to retain its Star designation. 

Lilly has also been a part of the American Chemistry Council (ACC) Responsible Care® initiative since it was enacted by the U.S. chemical industry in 1988.  Responsible Care is the chemical manufacturing industrys environmental, health, safety and security performance initiative and is aimed at helping member companies enhance performance and improve the health and safety of their employees, the communities in which they operate and the environment as a whole.  At Lilly our strategy has been to integrate the Responsible Care Guiding Principles into our Global HSE Procedure and HSE Standards.  Internal assessments and external audits occur on a three-year frequency to confirm conformance.

Lilly takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

	Process safety information
	Process hazard analysis
	Operating procedures
	Training
	Mechanical integrity
	Management of change
	Pre-startup review
	Compliance audits
	Incident investigation
	Employee participation
	Hot work permit
	Contractors

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees

are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.

4.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The LTC has had no accidents as defined in 40 CFR 68.42 during the past five years.

5.  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Emergency Management at Lilly Technology Center
The LTC emergency response plan is linked to the plans of the Marion County Emergency Planning Committee.  The sites response is coordinated by plant security using the plants emergency response teams and equipment.  The emergency response plan spells out the hows of emergency response and the roles and responsibilities of the incident response and management response teams.  It includes response procedures that are applicable for each building/area of the plant.  Periodic tabletops, functional drills and exercises test readiness and help employees practice responses to alarms and incidents.  The emergency response plan has been written based upon the one-plan EPA guidance and covers all topics based on that guidance.

RAVE System
The LTC implemented an innovative community emergency notification system in 1996.  The RAVE system is an automated phone messaging system that can send a recorded message to everyone who lives or works within one mile of the plant site.  The system calls every number up to three times if there is no answer initially.  It also generates a report advising what phones were not answered.

Lilly Fire Rescue (LFR)
The Lilly Indianapolis plant sites have a trained emergency response team, Lilly Fire Rescue (LFR), made up of full time emergency staff and trained extended staff members (volunteers who have other job duties but can be called as needed). LFR is trained as an all hazard response team including Fire, Rescue, HazMat and EMS. LFR will respond to any emergency situation on the plant site when called. When Security ha

s been notified that an emergency has occurred via telephone (555), radio, alarm or other means, Security dispatches the LFR full time staff along with the LFR extended staff who are in or near the incident area to immediately report to the incident scene to verify that an emergency exists and respond as necessary.  

LFR undergoes regular training to meet Local, State, Federal and Company requirements. On-site training facilities and simulators facilitate the training process.  In an emergency situation, one of the site emergency coordinators (or designate) becomes the incident commander.  LFR has the responsibility for maintaining the emergency response equipment. Vehicles on-site include the following:  ambulance (2), quick strike pumper truck, officer response truck, hazardous materials response truck, rescue truck and fire engine.

Hazardous Material (HAZMAT) Team Hazardous material response is part of the LFR training and includes responding to hazardous spills or vapor releases.  LFR personnel are trained to the Hazmat Technician level and to use proper equipment and techniques to stabilize a hazardous area and rescue employees who may need help.  This team undergoes rigorous monthly training in HAZMAT response.  

Confined Space Rescue Team
Part of the training for LFR also includes Confined Space Rescue.  LFR specializes in rescue from tanks, pits, and other confined areas.  LFR is trained to use ropes, mechanical rescue and high angle rescue techniques.

Medical First Responders
Part of the training for LFR also includes Emergency Medical Response.  LFR personnel are trained to give emergency medical aid.  All first responders are certified in CPR, first aid, and defibrillation.  In addition, most LFR personnel have received state certification to the level of Emergency Medical Technician (EMT).

Fire Response
LFR personnel are state certified (Firefighter I and II) and are trained to address structural fires in the incipient stage and chemical fires.  If
